etymologies: late Middle English: from late Latin contagiosus, from contagio (see contagion)

notes.text: Strictly, a contagious disease is one transmitted by physical contact, whereas an infectious one is transmitted via microorganisms in the air or water. In practice, there is little or no difference in meaning between contagious and infectious when applied to disease or its spread. In figurative senses, contagious may describe the spread of good things such as laughter and enthusiasm or bad ones such as violence or panic, whereas infectious usually refers to the spread of positive things, such as good humor or optimism

definitions: (of a disease) spread from one person or organism to another by direct or indirect contact
shortDefinitions: (of disease) spread from one person or organism to another

definitions: (of a person or animal) likely to transmit a disease by contact with other people or animals

examples.text: precautions are taken with anyone who seems contagious

shortDefinitions: (of person) having disease that can be transmitted by contact with other people

definitions: (of an emotion, feeling, or attitude) likely to spread to and affect others
shortDefinitions: likely to spread to and affect others
